choices.C: Requirement will be adopted in the solution

questions.question_text:
You are performing a fit gap analysis for a bank based in the United States.

The bank requires a solution to monitor and disclose all financial transactions where money laundering is suspected.

You know that this requirement may not be feasible because banks and other financial institutions must adhere to established laws, rules, and guidelines.

You need to verify the feasibility of the requirement.

Which feasibility analysis should you check for the requirement?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
Compliance: Financial institutions, especially banks, must adhere to strict regulatory requirements, such as the Bank Secrecy Act (BSA) and Anti-Money Laundering (AML) regulations in the United States. These regulations set standards for monitoring, detecting, and reporting suspicious financial transactions.

Verifying whether the requirement aligns with compliance standards means ensuring that the solution not only complies with legal and regulatory frameworks but also meets the standards and guidelines set by government and regulatory bodies.

questions.question_text:
DRAG DROP
-

A company plans to simplify its environment by replacing its current applications with a Microsoft Power Platform solution.

You need to guide the company through the activities required during each project phase.

When should you recommend the company perform each activity? To answer, move the appropriate phases to the correct activities. You may use each phase once, more than once, or not at all. You may need to move the split bar between panes or scroll to view content.

NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.

//IMG//

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AE
Remember, this is for the current enterprise architecture (this architectural diagram)
A. Data locations (most definitely)
E. Applications Used (I would have put the technology platform, but this works)

Who cares about 'organizational structure' as it pertains to the architecture. Process diagrams are the low level items (more details) that will support the high level architecture diagram. 'Functional requirements' are the details going into a requirements document or Agile/Project Management software.

comments.content:
I Agree AE is the correct answer

Why not the other options:
B. Organizational structure: While organizational structure is important for understanding the roles and relationships within the company, it does not directly impact the technical aspects of the enterprise architecture.

C. Process diagrams: Process diagrams are useful for mapping business workflows, but they are part of the business architecture and not the core enterprise architecture components like data or applications.

D. Functional requirements: Functional requirements describe what the company needs from the system, but they are typically gathered later in the process, after understanding the architecture and data flow.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BE
B and E - enterprise architecture is different from solution architecture (as concepts). However, in the context of this exam, they are probably miswording the question..
